transcripts.text: Let's go for it.
Okay, cool.  First, I want to go to River in Michigan.  Hey, River in Michigan, you are live with Truth Wanted.  What's going on?
Hey, can you hear me?
Yes, I can hear you just fine.

Hey, I've called into this show before, and last time it was about specifically objective morality, but I've actually, my thoughts have changed a lot in a lot of different areas since then.  But the specific question I wanted to ask is, I've been having trouble because I have obsessive-compulsive disorder, which led to those problems with objective morality in the first place.  And I've gotten to the point where I have trouble believing anything at all.  I'm so skeptical of everything, including the axioms of logic itself and knowledge itself and so on.  Like, is anything true or false?

River, did you know there's a name for that?  There is?  There is.  It's called Pyronic Skepticism.  Okay.  So there was this guy.  I don't know.  Was his name Pyron?  I can't remember his name.  But it's called Pyron of Skepticism because there was this Greek philosopher who was like super cynical and so skeptical that he kind of just burned everything down and couldn't take anything for granted, even knowledge itself, even skepticism itself.  I guess he was skeptical of.  And yeah, that's – I would say – I've definitely experienced that myself too.  I'm sure Rebecca probably has gotten to that point.
Yeah, for sure.

As far as solutions to that, that's an interesting question because I think different people will deal with it in different ways.  I think at some point you got to accept like, yeah, I might be a brain in a vat, but I can still process things.  I can still have inputs and interpret those inputs.  And I can navigate the world with some accuracy, you know, like, so, you know, maybe they are at least useful.  Maybe they're not true divine knowledge, but, you know, there is some value to it and I can sleep well at night with that.  What do you think?

Yeah.  So like, That's a problem that I've thought about before, brain in a vat, and that was actually one of the reasons I left religion was that problem specifically.  Because I was like, if I'm a brain in a vat, well, even if these – and I found out later that the historical accounts weren't reliable.  But even if these historical accounts of Jesus are true, if I'm a brain in a vat, what good are they?  How could I – use this worldly knowledge to say, oh, there's something outside of reality that's divine.  And I'm like, no, I can't do that.  So, but I have no problem with accepting that I will never know that I'm a brand or not.  What's a bigger problem with me is when I can't, like, even if I don't have perfect certainty, which is perfect certainty, I would define as knowing that you can't be wrong.  So some people think they have perfect certainty that there can't be a square circle or there can't be a triangle with more than three sides.  I don't even need that.  I just need some way to operate and say, hey, based on my observation, this is most likely.  And OCD has basically just taken that away from me.  And I'm just wondering, how can I convince myself when I'm so... skeptical and, quote-unquote, I say illogical, but I haven't even established logic yet, to the point where I just want to escape this hole I've dug myself into, which is...
Epistemic nihilism, really, kind of, is what it is.
Yeah, that's basically what it is.
Yeah.  I mean, I think Rebecca looks like she has some thoughts on it.
Yeah, I think...

It's interesting.  you're saying how you don't necessarily want perfect certainty.  But I think in a way, and I don't know whether this is a religious thing or where it comes from, but this idea of perfect certainty is what's really fucking us all up.  This is why we get into this situation because we have this idea.  It's like if you think mermaids exist and then all day you're out looking for mermaids and you never find any mermaids because they don't exist.  And then someone goes, hey, look at this manatee.  And you're like, well, that's not a mermaid.  That's bullshit.  But it's a manatee.  They're amazing creatures.  So the fact that you have this idea of perfect certainty, and I'm not saying this is what you're going for, but the fact we human beings have the idea of perfect certainty, it's like a supernormal stimulus, that idea of something that feels so good to us.  It's too good to us because it presses all the feel-good buttons in our brains.  And then we can't accept reality, which is uncertain.  I mean, reality maybe isn't uncertain, but we will never be certain of reality.  So, I mean, like it's really difficult and maybe there is no answer.  But what I found really helpful when I get into these, and this is, it's not uncommon at all.  In fact, people talked about this in responses to the How We Let Go survey, exactly, epistemic nihilism, is to do physical things, to do things that... you don't have to be thinking so much.  So a lot of people talk about meditation and simple movements, and that's something that I would enjoy and recommend.  Also just going out for a walk and feeling the weight of your feet on the ground.  You don't need to think, you just need to feel, just for short times.  And that was also obviously the sort of advice that you probably heard a lot with OCD, but I think it's useful for this sort of philosophical problems as well as the mental health stuff.  So I don't know, maybe you've heard that before, but that's all I got.

So I'm reminded of there's this South Park episode from a few years ago.  It was a two-parter where I believe it's Stan.  They kind of do a parody of The Matrix where he kind of wakes up and realizes reality is all shit.  And when I mean shit, I mean literally shit.  Like there's actual poop everywhere and stuff.  And he's kind of seeing stuff.
I remember this one.

Yeah, and it's like kind of almost depressing.  It's like, oh, man, I can relate to that.  And you have this thought of.  I wonder how the writers are going to resolve this plot.  Like what is the solution here?  And the end resolution is kind of like, well, he kind of just has to live with it.  Like he doesn't go back.  He's still seeing this stuff.  And that really struck with me because it's like, yeah, like we can get to that point.  But at the end of the day, you still got to eat.  You still got to move on and live and do something.  Yeah.  And at this point, it's like, well, as a human being, I have to define my own set of values and figure out what I'm going to do.  And I tend to find nobility in trying to find truth and talking to other people about truth, wanting truth.  And, you know, just like figuring stuff out and helping out other people on their path because I can be just as confused as everybody else.  I certainly don't have all the answers.  But I can find peace in the fact that, hey, at least I'm a little bit closer than I was yesterday to not believing in things that were wrong.  You know, like we can at least filter up the stuff that we know is like super not true.  So I think there's nobility in that.  But that's going to be different for everybody.  So I don't know.  What do you think, River?

So, like, it comes – yeah, that's – I call that.  the dead end is when you find a realization and you can't find a way out of it.  Like, for example, South Park.  They find out that the reality is literally shit.  And they're like, well, this is a dead end because there's no way I'm going to convince myself that it's otherwise.  And so I might as well live with it.  I mean, at least – At that point, you also have to realize that not only at the base level, yeah, it's true, reality is literal feces, but it's also all these sensory things that don't appear to be feces, and so that's something too.  And so even if reality is a simulation, for example, that's not the only thing that exists.  There also exists all the sensory experiences that it creates, And that's something valuable in and of itself.  that's not – it doesn't matter what it's created by, if it's created by atoms or if it's created by ones and zeros.

Yeah.  So Soren Kierkegaard talks about this.  He would have called himself – I mean the language we use now is Christian existentialist because he kind of realized, man, I can't – I can't prove this thing, this God belief that I have.  But I'm just going to take the leap of faith and live my life to, you know, whatever it is.  Now, obviously, I would disagree with Kierkegaard.  I don't think we should make quite the same leaps of faith that he did.  But we do have to make a leap of faith by saying, yeah, I don't think I'm a brain in a vat because I'm certainly not acting like it.  I'm certainly not trying to get out or whatever.  But, you know, even if I was, it almost does seem like I can't get out of it, right?  So... Again, it's kind of just making the best of the situation that we have and overcoming staring into the abyss and just figuring out, man, where do I go from here?  As someone who has OCD, I can't imagine what that's like because I don't have OCD myself.  I imagine that probably just multiplies kind of the angst that comes with that.  For me, this show is a great way of relieving that, talking with other people.  I think Rebecca's right.  Even if it's just a walk, even if it's just some sort of exercise that you can relax and realize that, hey, everything is okay.  I'm still here.  I'm just moving on, living life.  All things considered, I can say for myself, I'm a pretty lucky person to be where I'm at.  And I hope other people can say the same for themselves, and I hope you can too, River.  But yeah, as far as like, here's the chemical formula to get you out of it.  Man, I don't have that, and I think you're right.  I'm not sure anybody does.
I think it's... Sorry, go on.

Sorry, yeah, that's... I mean, that's fine with me in a way.  So I'm just having this difficulty because OCD... it's like the ultimate call-out machine.  It calls me out on everything, even when I think I'm right.  And so this morning I was like, well, I don't care if I do one small thing wrong.  If I do one small thing wrong, I have the power to do that thing wrong, and I'll use doing that wrong and finding out that it's wrong as a vehicle to move towards truth.  And I don't care what the reality is.  I'm just going to Move forward.  and because it questions whether I should just do nothing or do the things that I want.

Yes.  One of the oldest questions of philosophy, right?  Whether or not someone should kill themselves.  I mean, seriously, that's a thing people have been contemplating for a long time.  What do you do?  Like, it's tough.  Yeah, it's the human condition.  But anyway, go on.

But I just said, you know what?  I make the decisions around here.  I am in control of this body.  I'm going to go do what I want to do.  And I'm going to live to the highest values that I want to be true.  So I want it to be true that there are things I should and should not do.  So I'm going to live up to those values until I either find out that they're correct or they're not.  But I was doing this for a little bit, and it worked pretty well until OCD was like, You're being dishonest with yourself.  You're lying to yourself.  You're not being honest.  And I couldn't really have a response to that.  And so I went back to the stagnation, and that's pretty much where I am now.  So I'm trying to find a way to get out of it.  But it's okay if you don't have the perfect formula, because it's something I figured out over time.  Sure.
Rebecca had something to say.

Yeah, I don't think... I mean, I've had similar conversations with myself, and I can see why you would go to that thought that you're being dishonest with yourself.  But I don't think it is dishonest, because... even if we can't know for sure, like what's really going on because we're only human beings with human brains, you can sort of do, and I hate to invoke this sort of Christian apologist talk, but you can do a Pascal's wager on this, right?  So if, if you're, If you're right that, like, saying, you know, other people matter and other people's subjective experiences matter and we should treat them well, and you decide not to do that, then that's really bad.  But if you're wrong and other people don't matter and it's just a solipsistic nightmare, like, you're just alone in the universe, you're just a brain, you're not even a brain, and you carry on acting as if other people matter and being a good person, that doesn't do any harm at all.  So that like, if you just do a basic trade off on those decisions, you can say, I don't know for sure, but in the absence of complete surety, I'm going to act in the way that is most likely to be, you know, to be the best result.
Yeah.
No, that sounds good.

Yeah.  I like that.  Yeah, I think at the end of the day, you're always going to be making appeals to your own value system, and you can't escape that.  And that's something people struggle with too.  because it's like, oh, I want to appear to this objective standard.  And it's like, yeah, whatever standard you figure out is right for you is going to be because you figured out it's right for you.  Ultimately, you are in the way of whatever thing you find to be fulfilling for you.  And so you might as well work with that.  Might as well try to understand that and live that so that you can have a good life because that's – as far as I know, that's all we can do.  So anyway, River, this was a great conversation.  I want to get to some other folks here, but thanks so much for calling in.  Thank you.
Thank you very much.

Yeah, absolutely.  I hope you find what you're looking for.  I hope you can talk to somebody about your OCD as well, someone definitely more expert than Rebecca and I as well because I know that can't be fun, and that's not something I struggle with.  I really can't relate.  In my personal life, I can be very messy.  Doing work is fine.  I can do that stuff, but, like, I don't know.  I don't know how people do that, you know?
